string_table.name: pxabnsnfns10111111101
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidelink.displaytext: Question: True or False there are barriers to accessibility?
Question: ____________________ is formed by what individuals do, how they interact with their surroundings and are created to fit their personal preferences.
Question: What does the POUR acronym stand for?
Question: What are three ways we can determine a learners need for accessible formats?
Question: Which of the following is an accommodation you can give to a student with a visual impairment?

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: National Center on Accessible Educational Materials

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="72" Justification="Left" ListLevel="2" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Before we begin this interactive training, it is important to know how to navigate through the course should an issue arise. Please make note of the following items. At the top left of your screen, you will see the menu icon. The menu icon will allow you to navigate through the different sections of the training. Once the training begins you can advance slides by clicking on the next icon located at the bottom right of the screen. If for any reason you need to preview the previous slide, then you can click the previous icon and it will take you back to the previous slide. If you would like to enable or disable the closed captions at any time in the training, you may do so by clicking on the cc icon at the bottom of the screen. Finally, you will see the play button at the bottom left of the screen. You can use this button to play or pause the training at any time. Now, lets get started! Please press the next icon at the bottom of the screen." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="This training should only take you 10-15 minutes to complete. Throughout this training -you will be tested on your knowledge of accessibility and explore ways that you can make educational materials accessible for all of your students in your classroom. To receive a passing grade for this training you must finish it in its entirety and receive a 75% or higher on the final assessment." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The Big Idea for this interactive lesson is that K-12 educators will be able to explore how to provide accessible learning materials for those students with physical or learning disabilities. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Hello! My is Lydia and today we will be discussing why accessibility for educational materials matters. I am an instructional designer with experience working with K-12 learners. Now, that you know my name please enter your name in the text box located on the screen. After that I would like you to take a self-assessment on what you know about accessibility. You will be asked a series of questions to test your understanding of accessibility. So, Lets get started! " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Accessibility is established by what individuals do, how they interact with their surroundings and are catered to fit their personal preferences. Educational materials are considered accessible to individuals with disabilities when they can acquire the same information, engage in the same interactions and enjoy the same services. It is important to remember that what is accessible to an individual with a physical disability is not necessarily accessible to an individual with a learning disability. For this reason, it is essential to ask yourself to whom is your curriculum accessible to? Under what conditions is the curriculum need or used for and what task is it used for?" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="2" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Although accessibility is required by law there are barriers educators face in developing curriculum that is inclusive to the needs of their students with disabilities. It is important to be aware of the barriers that can affect students learning and educational opportunities. It is our job to remove those barriers we have control over. In this portion of the training, we are going to discuss these barriers and discuss ways we can work towards removing these barriers." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Barrier #1 to accessibility is attitudinal. Attitudinal barriers often come from a lack of knowledge or understanding about individuals with disabilities, this can cause people to have misconceptions and can even lead to discrimination. Click on the icon on the screen to explore examples of attitudunal barriers. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Barrier #2 to accessibility is organizational or systemic. Although these barriers are often put into place unintentionally, they are policies, procedures and practices that can discriminate against individuals with disabilities and keep them from gaining full access to situations. Click on the icon on the screen to explore examples of organizational or systemic barriers." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Barrier #3 to Accessibility is architectural or physical. These elements cause a barrier for individuals with disabilities because they can have a difficult time gaining access to a building or room. Additionally, the layout of a classroom, a buildings stairs and the width of a hallway can all cause a barrier. Click on the icon on the screen to explore examples of architectural or physical barriers." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Barrier #4 to accessibility is information and communication. Information and communication barriers correlate to sending and receiving information. Individuals with sensory disability such as hearing impairment, visual impairment and learning disabilities are not considered in the communication process. Click on the icon on the screen to explore examples of informational or communication barriers." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Barrier #5 to accessibility is technology. Technology barriers occur when a device is not inclusive to it intended audience and is unable to be used as an assistive device. Click on the icon on the screen to explore technology barriers. Once, you are finished exploring technology please advance to the next slide where you will be asked to answer a few questions. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="We have been discussing the importance of accessibility and weve discussed how there can be barriers to developing accessible curriculum. I want you take a few moments to search for your favorite song on YouTube. Click on the icon on the screen to access YouTube. Once you have found your favorite song, I would like for you to watch it with the closed captions on and take note if the captions matched the pacing of the lyrics of the song and see how accurate the captioning is. Once you are finished investigating your favorite song return to the training and answer a few questions about your experience. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Accessibility guidelines can be confusing and abundant. So where can we start when vetting our resources to use within our classroom. We can use the POUR principles which stands for perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust. By following each guideline of the acronym, you can ensure that the digital materials and technologies you are using are accessible." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="P is for perceivable. Perceivable materials are flexible in formatting to take into consideration the various way learners recognize information. Click on the icons on this page to explore ways to utilize this in the classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="O is for Operable. Operable material allows users to navigate through the course content and gives learners various way to control the interface. Click on the icon on the screen to explore ways to utilize this in the classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="U is for understandable. Understandable means does the materials presented make sense, are they ordered in a logical manner and in predicable ways? Click on the icon on the screen to explore ways to utilize this in the classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="R is for Robust. Robust materials can work with current and future technologies. Click on the icon on the screen to explore ways to utilize this in the classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Laws guarantee individuals with disabilities access to education and employment opportunities. Because of this many school districts are obligated to provide accessible formats for individuals with disabilities. There are actions we can take to make sure that learners receive the formatting they need. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Determining the learners needs is the first step in deciding what format to use. In a K-12 programs this process is determined by an IEP team or 504 plan teams as well as parents. The teams consider three possibilities when determining the learners need for accessibility. The first possibility they look into is evidence that show that the learner can read and access the information given from the same text-based instructional guides across the curriculum by all students. If students demonstrate understanding, then they do not need any interventions given. The second possibility they consider is if the learners is experiencing some difficulty reading the materials presented in the current format being used. In this case they would anticipate that the students will make adequate progress if the information is presented in more than one format. In this case the learners would need a few interventions at that time. Finally, the last possibility they consider is if the learner needs modified content. Like a lower reading level. In this case the team would determine whether the learner needs modified content only or a combination of accessible formats and modified content." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="When determining what formats to use the team will consider multiple factors. These factors are how, where and what purposed learners will use the instructional materials. They take into consideration the learners skill, needs and personal preferences. They also consider the students learning environment and what task for which format is needed. They then have the learner trial a variety of formats. For example, tactile formats, large print formats and audio formats. After students have finished their trial of formats the team selects the format or combination of formats the learn will need. Finally, the team will match formats to ensure the text-based material matched the needs of the learner." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Once you have determined accessibility formats for learners in your classroom you can then begin to personalize their learning experience. Using material that had web access can help provide the learner with a unique reading experience. Using online materials can help you customize how the information is displayed, you reduce the effort it takes for learners to read using eBooks, webpages, app and digital content." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="To explore ways you can customize display information click the icon on the screen to explore how to use these features in your classroom. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Now that you understand what accessibility means in the classroom you will be given different scenario where you will be asked to provide the best accommodations for your students. Click the next button to begin the role play scenarios. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: The Big Idea for this interactive lesson is that K-12 educators will be able to explore how to provide accessible learning materials for those students with physical or learning disabilities.
Accessibility is established by what individuals do, how they interact with their surroundings and are catered to fit their personal preferences.
Accessible formats are printed, written or visual materials provided for students with disabilities.

These elements cause a barrier for individuals with disabilities because they can have a difficult time gaining access to a building or room. Additionally, the layout of a classroom, a buildings stairs and the width of a hallway can all cause a barrier.
Attitudinal barriers often come from a lack of knowledge or understanding about individuals with disabilities, which can cause people to have misconceptions and can even lead to discrimination.
A barrier of learning is anything that would prevent an individual from being fully involved in the learning process.

Information and communication barriers correlate to sending and receiving information. Individuals with sensory disability such as hearing impairment, visual impairment and learning disabilities are not considered in the communication process.
Barriers that are put in place that can dicriminate againt individuals with disabilites.
Technology barriers occur when a device is not inclusive to it intended audience and is unable to be used as an assistive device.
